text: secure sharing and distributions of data
and insights is a key value proposition
offered by Amazon quick site in this
video let's take a look at how you can
share data and insights within your
organization let's start with an
analysis you have the option of sharing
this analysis with another quick site
user who will then become a co-owner
this means that once shared you and any
shared owners can modify and make
changes to the analysis you can easily
manage the sharing permissions
associated with the analysis and revoke
permissions if needed
now if we wanted to publish this as a
read-only entity you can create a
dashboard from this analysis using this
option we'll publish the analysis as a
dashboard which other users can access
they will not see the few dwells or be
able to modify the fields included in an
analysis but you will be able to drill
down and apply filters as needed data in
the dashboard will always be the latest
weather from spice or from a direct
query data source using a dashboard with
an underlying spice data set that is
periodically refreshed will allow you to
extend interactive dashboards to a large
audience in your organization another
way to allow others access to your data
in Amazon quick site is by sharing a
data set this option allows
administrators to share curated data
with a set of users
the users can be restricted for
any additional data from the source but
the administrator can refresh the data
to provide the latest this allows you to
create many data Mart's that can enable
data exploration by business users while
making sure that data permission
requirements are in place permissions to
shared datasets can also be easily
revoked making management of data very
easy
now let's take a look at stories which
make for a great way to present an
insight let's focus on this dataset
where we are looking at revenues for a
fictional software company through a
story we'd like to communicate how the
revenues for the API channel are growing
and what are the major drivers of growth
to start with let's create a graph of
the overall distribution of revenues a
pie chart makes a good start
now let's capture that as a scene in our
story and label it
for our next scene let's look into the
Oracle trend in revenues where we see
that the API has been slow to grow
compared to our web and mobile channels
we add this to the story and then
continue now focusing on the API alone
using the field Wells we can quick
Tibbett the chart to display revenues
for API across regions and change the
title accordingly we could choose to
modify the colors here - if so desired
now let's focus on the largest market
for API which is the US and pivot the
chart to understand how we've been
growing across segments to compare
across segments within the years let's
switch to a bar chart trying both the
stacked and clustered bar options
the clustered bomb a
easy to compare so let's use that for
the next scene as you can see our
revenues from startups are more than two
times the revenues from enterprises
which we believe to be one of our key
growth areas so definitely something for
the sales team to focus on now that the
story is in place you can use the play
button to play the insight to the right
audience we've seen how quick site
provides a number of options to share

that suits your situation the best and
enable your fellow quick site users
